text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Chairman of committee supervising the transition to civil rule programme Justice Mamman Nasir says 1998 date to hand over to an elected president is irrevocable.
- Onne port in the southeast declared free trade zone with implication of lower costs for oil firms operating there.
- Production at Delta steel plant in the midwest grinds to halt; staff owed 10 months salary arrears and about 400 million naira needed to resuscitate the government-owned firm.
- Central bank raises interest rates on treasury bills to 6.3 percent from around three percent previously to attract investments in debt instruments.

- Government is dissatisfied with its oil joint ventures and will opt for production sharing contracts whereby oil firms bear exploration costs and recoup their investments if oil is found, finance minister Anthony Ani restates to reporters in Abuja.
- Visiting African human rights team meets government officials in Abuja on Monday.
- Soaring prices of blue chip firms on the stock exchange worries brokers who say it will put pressure on the companies to declare higher dividend than they can afford.
- Federal government cautions electoral commission against unnecessary disqualification of candidates for March 15 local council polls.
- Government may grant visiting African human rights team access to detained presidential claimant Moshood Abiola and other detainees.
- Finance minister says transfer of accounts of government agents to commercial banks from the central bank to wait so as to control liquidity level.
- Nigerian Liquefied Natural Gas Company says awaiting concrete proposals from Italian firm Enel on stalled contract to buy Nigerian gas
